title: Chronic Pressure Ulcer
diagnosis_topic: Sacral pressure injury in immobile elderly patient
setup_script: An 80-year-old woman residing in a nursing home is brought in for evaluation of a sacral ulcer that has not healed over two months. She is bedbound and has dementia.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/70 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.3 C.
4 cm x 5 cm ulcer over sacrum with exposed subcutaneous fat (stage III) and minimal exudate; surrounding skin macerated.
Prolonged immobility, incontinence, poor nutritional status and cognitive impairment identified.
Albumin 2.5 g/dL, prealbumin low; mild anemia.
Recommend repositioning every 2 hours, use of pressure-relieving mattress and avoidance of friction/shear.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident arranges debridement of necrotic tissue
dynamic_flow.reply: Sharp debridement performed; wound cleaned and dressed appropriately.
Apply moist dressings such as hydrocolloid or foam; avoid cytotoxic agents.
Cultures obtained if signs of infection; systemic antibiotics started for osteomyelitis if bone involvement suspected.
High-protein, high-calorie diet and vitamin supplementation recommended; consider tube feeding if inadequate oral intake.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers surgical flap coverage
dynamic_flow.reply: For stage III/IV ulcers failing conservative therapy, referral to plastic surgery for flap closure discussed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates staff and caregivers
dynamic_flow.reply: Importance of repositioning, skin inspection and hygiene emphasized.
Regular assessment of ulcer size, depth and signs of healing or deterioration documented.

critical_decision_points: Comprehensive assessment and staging of pressure ulcers
Identification and correction of contributing factors (pressure, moisture, nutrition)
Appropriate debridement and topical wound management
Recognition and treatment of infection and osteomyelitis
Consideration of surgical closure and prevention strategies
